title: Is saying “or not” after “whether” redundant? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is often redundant, but not always. The usage of “whether” inherently implies a binary choice, so “or not” isn’t necessary all the time. When there is an obvious choice, simply using whether is more appropriate. Whether or not it arrives on the 4th doesn’t matter to me.Whether it arrives on the 4th doesn’t matter to me.These two statements mean something slightly different. The first is the binary choice of the 4th being OK for it to arrive. Turns out it doesn’t matter. The second is less of a binary choice and more of a vague condition where any of the parts of the sentence could be different. Whether it or its twin arrives on the 4th doesn’t matter to me.Whether it arrives or departs on the 4th doesn’t matter to me.Whether it arrives on the 4th or the 5th doesn’t matter to me.Another way of using whether is a bit more problematic in terms of redundancy. When you’re talking about a binary choice that might or might not factor in to a larger condition, it can be more confusing not to include the “or not”. I always see myself as ugly, whether I really am.I always see myself as ugly, whether or not I really am.The condition of being ugly is treated as a binary condition, but the usage of whether without the “or not” here doesn’t sound right.

Is saying “or not” after “whether” redundant? This will seem like an odd introduction, but… There are times a person will use or abuse a turn of phrase due to their background and community, but it’s condescending to assume that’s the same as being ignorant or “wrong”. A privileged person is insufficiently committed to inclusion and diversity if he allows a turn of phrase like this to distract him from what the writer/speaker has to say. Dropping the “or not” from “whether or not” subtly communicates that a matter isn’t quite binary, and its most important aspect might not be one of exactly two possible conditions or outcomes. A simple example: Q: Did you follow the instructions? A: I don’t really know whether or not I did but it’s done and it works. Typically it means the person followed the instructions, but some things were unclear and so it’s possible a minor step was done differently than expected. Subtle humility. A: I don’t really know whether I did but it’s done and it works. Typically, the person felt the matter was simple enough that the instructions were infrequently consulted. Subtly cavalier. A person may choose their words more carefully than you (or they) consciously realize. Stop trying to find reasons to tell yourself that you’re smarter than them.

Original Question: Is saying "or not" after whether redundant? It is redundant. “Whether” includes the element of choice, and the default alternative when not stated is “or not.” Sentences where you’re using “whether” will not change in meaning when you exclude “or not.” “I can’t decide whether or not to go to my cousin’s Christening.”“I can’t decide whether to go to my cousin’s Christening.”There are circumstances where “or not” is not the alternative, but in those cases you’d follow the initial declaration with a specific alternative: “I can’t decide whether to go to my cousin’s Christening or to my friend’s wedding.”

I see the options as being more of a personal choice that applies at the time of the conversation and if emphasis is also being used, whether or not people agree with me is another matter. The expression whether or not being chosen to the way each person has been led to use it, such as copying others who have done this previously. The phrase is sometimes used with hand gestures to convey the choices, such as left or right or up or down or even the use of the hand being quickly or slowly swivelled left and right, to suggest how iffy the choices could be for some.

Yes. I would think so. Since it is implied, saying or writing “or not" after “whether” in sentences that presuppose a ‘yes or no’ option, is redundant. And in sentences where the options are more than two, the “or not" after “whether", I feel, has no meaning. Let me know whether you will attend the meeting. (“or not” is not a ‘must' here.)I have no idea whether he liked it, hated it or just didn't care. (“or not” after “whether” will look out of place here.)Am eager to know others' views as well on this.

Saying “whether or not” is unconditional. Whether you understand this or not does not change the conditions. (A) Whether you attend the game or not will not change the score. (B) Whether you play the game or sit out could make a difference. Statement A is unconditionally true. Statement B is also true. If B were to use “or not” it would not change the statement but allows unspecified conditions to change the meaning.

No - in fact, without the “or not”, it doesn’t always make sense. Compare “ I will do this whether or not you agree.”.. with“ I will do this whether you agree.”The second isn’t quite right. “Whether” is used to indicate alternative conditions: whether this or that. Here’s an example of another way:“seated him next to her whether by accident or design” There is another case:“I wonder whether I should stay.” So sometimes the “or not” can be omitted, but it’s safer to put it in:“I wonder whether I should stay or not.” Or even“I wonder whether I should stay or go.”

No, it’s not always redundant. These sentences don’t make sense without it: I’m leaving whether you like it or not.The author makes a strong case for her point of view, whether or not you accept it. And these sentences mean different things: It doesn’t matter whether the supermarket sells apples or oranges.It doesn’t matter whether or not the supermarket sells apples or oranges.

The usage is, either: ‘whether xxx or yyy’, or: ‘whether xxx or not’. If you do not specify ‘not’ as an option, then the question becomes more open ended — not answerable in monosyllabic ‘yes’ or ‘no’ — expecting the optional second a ‘worded’ reply. Both the usages, ‘Whether xxx or not’ and ‘whether xxx or yyy’, essentially involve two choices and, therefore, are to be used contextually. The former is often used in questions.  The two examples illustrated: “Whether you marry Mary or Jane is immaterial.” “Whether you marry Mary or not is immatterial.” OR, “Whether or not you marry Mary, is immaterial.” Dropping ‘not’ from the second sentence will not be right, as it will alter the meaning — the alternative remaining unspecified.

Not quite the same but a not too unusual thing around here (Geordyland) is to say “Shall I do this - or not? Completely redundant and confusing. The idiot I worked with for the last three years would add “or not” to almost every question. The manager would always want know “Where’s Joe Soap at” instead of “Where’s Joe Soap”? Just as bad.

When using “whether” one has the choice to put “or not” after it if one so chooses. Example “ Could you phone Mary and ask her “whether” she is coming on the trip?” Or “ Could you phone Mary and ask her “whether or not” she is coming on the trip?” The actual meaning in both sentences is exactly the same. “Or not” redundant? I’m not sure.

Whether or not you agree with me, I would say it is often not redundant and can add something to the balance and rhythm of a sentence. Try this on your ear: “Whether or not you feel like taking the medicine, you have to.” Now say it without “or not.”

No I wouldn’t say it’s redundant. Because for instance: “Whether or not you’re here is irrelevant. “ there, you need the or not because the sentence wouldn’t make sense without it,: “Whether you’re here is irrelevant.”

Most likely it is but it is one of those phrases that has lingered in the English (American) patois to show an emphatic questioning of a subject. It is almost a plea - “Whether you believe me or not, I love you….”

I've read more quotes with whether and or not as follows: No one asked whether you agree on this course of action or not. So proceed. It actually is redundant but serves as explanation. Languages are not entirely logical.

No, it’s not redundant. I’ve actually had some people use “or not” twice in the same sentence as “whether or not”, and that’d be redundant. “whether” is another word for “if”. So, it’s like say “if” and “if not”.

It depends on how ‘whether’ is used. The ‘or not’ is not redundant because it denotes something to follow. ‘I will be at the party whether or not the buses are running.’ Or, ‘It all depends whether I am invited.’

Whether or not you agree or whether you agree or not are both correct. Whether or not you agree, I’m determined to work overseas because I need a better paying job than if I don’t leave and settle for my job here.
The addition of the "or not" is neither logically nor grammatically required. I think it's often used conversationally for emphasis. I definitely wouldn't use it in writing myself.

Yes. That doesn't stop people, including me from saying it. Using it avoids the inference by the hearer/reader that the speaker/writer has a hidden positive or predictive opinion. After all, Shakespeare himself covered it, “to be or not to be”, when the alternative to being is automatically not to be.

No, I don't believe so. I tried making a sentence WITHOUT any such negative follow-up in the sentence, but it was difficult. It IS quite possible but seems to be lacking [or at least seems “eager” to come forth]. F.ex: “I explained it to her, but whether she really understood me, I can't say….I don't know….
No. It is a reversal of context
Yes.
